information:
Economic challenges and trade policy are key sources of market uncertainty. Tariffs imposed by the Trump administration have led to downward revisions of corporate earnings expectations. A Goldman Sachs model predicts that a 5% increase in tariffs could lead to a 1-2% decline in S&P 500 earnings per share. Sevens Report notes that even with reduced trade tensions, the base level of tariffs will remain much higher than in January, acting as a barrier to growth and a driver of inflation. Analysts at Barclays have expressed skepticism about whether there is enough momentum in U.S.-China trade discussions to avoid a U.S. recession.

In the week ending April 25, 2025, the S&P 500 index rose 4.6% to close at 5,525.21, its best weekly performance of the year to date. The Nasdaq Composite saw a 6.7% increase and the Dow Jones rose 2.5% during the same period. This rally was led by a recovery in large technology stocks. Despite the recent gains, market valuations are elevated, with the price-to-earnings ratio for the S&P 500 cited as being between 19 and 28, above historical averages. The VIX, a measure of market volatility, was recently observed at a high level of approximately 25.

Several market-moving events are scheduled for late April and early May 2025. Major technology companies, including Microsoft, Meta, Apple, and Amazon, are set to release their first-quarter earnings reports. In total, over 180 S&P 500 companies are expected to report. Key economic data releases are also imminent, including the report on first-quarter GDP growth, the Personal Consumer Expenditures (PCE) inflation gauge for March, the ISM Manufacturing Index for April, and the April employment report. The Federal Reserve's next policy meeting is scheduled for May 7.

forecast.time_left_until_outcome_known: About 1 month (until the final U.S. trading day of May 2025)
forecast.status_quo_outcome: Yes — historically the S&P 500 closes higher month-over-month roughly 55–60% of the time, implying a slight upward drift absent major shocks.
forecast.no_outcome_scenario: Hawkish Fed tone on May 7 and/or hotter-than-expected PCE/jobs data push rate-cut expectations further out; long yields rise, mega-cap guidance disappoints, and risk-off sentiment reverses the late-April tech-led rebound, leaving the May close below April’s.
forecast.yes_outcome_scenario: Mega-cap earnings broadly beat with solid guidance; inflation data cools or at least doesn’t re-accelerate; the Fed sounds patient but not more hawkish; Treasury yields stabilize or fall, sustaining risk appetite so the S&P 500 ends May above April’s close.
forecast.rationale:
Base rate: The S&P 500 posts positive monthly returns about 55–60% of the time, so the default tilt is modestly toward Yes. I anchor near that and then adjust for current conditions.
Adjustments from current context: 
- Bullish: A powerful late-April rebound led by large tech suggests ongoing AI/earnings momentum could carry into early May. A heavy earnings calendar can provide upside catalysts if guidance is resilient. If inflation data (PCE, later CPI timing relative to May close) is not worse than feared, and the Fed avoids surprising hawkishness on May 7, that supports a higher close by end-May.
- Bearish: Valuations are elevated (P/E cited 19–28), which increases sensitivity to rates and guidance. The VIX near ~25 signals heightened uncertainty and fatter tails. Sticky inflation in early 2025 raises the risk the Fed leans more hawkish, or at least delays cuts, which could pressure multiples. Trade/tariff policy and global growth concerns add headline risk.
Net effect: I put extra weight on the historical status-quo (world changes slowly) but shade down from ~60% given elevated valuations, policy/rate uncertainty, and a high VIX. I also note path dependence: if April’s final close is pushed very high by end-of-month strength, the hurdle for May increases; if April fades into month-end, the hurdle lowers. With those cross-currents, a slight positive edge remains, but not strong.
Why not higher: Elevated vol, rate path uncertainty, and tight valuations make a clean upside month less than the long-run 60%+ odds.
Why not lower: Earnings resilience from mega-caps and continued growth momentum provide meaningful support; a single month is often noise with a slight positive skew.
What would move me up: Broad beats/guidance from Apple/Amazon and other large caps; cooler inflation prints; 10-year yields drifting down; a Fed tone that rules out hikes and emphasizes confidence in disinflation.
What would move me down: Hot PCE/jobs, upside wage surprises, or a notably hawkish Fed; a guidance reset from mega-caps; renewed trade/tariff escalation; a sharp backup in real yields.

prompt:
You are a professional forecaster interviewing for a job.

Your interview question is:
Will the S&P 500 index go up in May 2025?

Question background:
NY Times: [What Is a Bear Market? Are We in One?](https://www.nytimes.com/article/bear-market-stocks-tariffs.html)


This question's outcome will be determined by the specific criteria below. These criteria have not yet been satisfied:
This question will resolve as Yes if the closing value of the S&P 500 Index on the final trading day of May 2025 is higher than that of the final trading day of April 2025.

The "close" values shown on the [history page of Yahoo finance](https://finance.yahoo.com/quote/%5EGSPC/history?p=%5EGSPC) will be used.


Your research assistant's report says:
Economic challenges and trade policy are key sources of market uncertainty. Tariffs imposed by the Trump administration have led to downward revisions of corporate earnings expectations. A Goldman Sachs model predicts that a 5% increase in tariffs could lead to a 1-2% decline in S&P 500 earnings per share. Sevens Report notes that even with reduced trade tensions, the base level of tariffs will remain much higher than in January, acting as a barrier to growth and a driver of inflation. Analysts at Barclays have expressed skepticism about whether there is enough momentum in U.S.-China trade discussions to avoid a U.S. recession.

In the week ending April 25, 2025, the S&P 500 index rose 4.6% to close at 5,525.21, its best weekly performance of the year to date. The Nasdaq Composite saw a 6.7% increase and the Dow Jones rose 2.5% during the same period. This rally was led by a recovery in large technology stocks. Despite the recent gains, market valuations are elevated, with the price-to-earnings ratio for the S&P 500 cited as being between 19 and 28, above historical averages. The VIX, a measure of market volatility, was recently observed at a high level of approximately 25.

Several market-moving events are scheduled for late April and early May 2025. Major technology companies, including Microsoft, Meta, Apple, and Amazon, are set to release their first-quarter earnings reports. In total, over 180 S&P 500 companies are expected to report. Key economic data releases are also imminent, including the report on first-quarter GDP growth, the Personal Consumer Expenditures (PCE) inflation gauge for March, the ISM Manufacturing Index for April, and the April employment report. The Federal Reserve's next policy meeting is scheduled for May 7.

Today is 2025-04-29.

Before answering you think:
(a) The time left until the outcome to the question is known.
(b) The status quo outcome if nothing changed.
(c) A brief description of a scenario that results in a No outcome.
(d) A brief description of a scenario that results in a Yes outcome.
(e) You write your rationale remembering that good forecasters put extra weight on the status quo outcome since the world changes slowly most of the time. Explain your reasoning and the evidence behind your forecast in detail. Summarise information your received from your research assistant that influences your forecast (if any). Explain why your forecast is not higher, and why it is not lower. Outline what would need to be true for you to update your forecast in either direction.
(f) The last thing you write is your final probabilistic forecast as a number between 0 and 100.

# OUTPUT SCHEMA
{
    "time_left_until_outcome_known": "string",
    "status_quo_outcome": "string",
    "no_outcome_scenario": "string",
    "yes_outcome_scenario": "string",
    "rationale": "string",
    "probability": "number" (0-100)
}
